channel.title: One Square Meter
channel.description: A year-long biodiversity documetation of 1m² area in Gundmi, India.

item.title: Sighting: Lesser Grass Blue
item.description:
Lesser Grass Blue (Zizina otis)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Butterfly! First one for this project!

Weather: 28.2°C, Foggy

item.title: Sighting: Common Green Bottle Fly
item.description:
Common Green Bottle Fly (Lucilia sericata)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Shiny, big and happy to sit still!

Weather: 28.2°C, Foggy

item.title: Sighting: Orange-headed Rice Leafhopper
item.description:
Orange-headed Rice Leafhopper (Thaia oryzivora)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

For a tiny bug, we definitely gave a really long name.

Weather: 28.3°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Snail-killing Fly
item.description:
Snail-killing Fly (Sciomyzidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

They and snails are not good friends. Infact they might be enemies.

Weather: 28.3°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Face Fly
item.description:
Face Fly (Musca sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Looks very similar to common housefly. But the AI says it ain't. Hail the algorithms!

Weather: 28.3°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Picture-winged Fly
item.description:
Picture-winged Fly (Tephritidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Another type of fruitfly, that does not eat any fruits.

Weather: 28.3°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Rainbow Jumping Spider
item.description:
Rainbow Jumping Spider (Chrysilla volupe)

Category: Arachnid | Season: Winter

What a little jewel, I am not sure of the species yet.

Weather: 27.8°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Planthopper Nymph
item.description:
Planthopper Nymph (Metadelphax propinqua)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Very tiny being. Camera just refused to auto-focus.

Weather: 27.8°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Ghost Ant
item.description:
Ghost Ant (Tapinoma melanocephalum)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Very small, very small. Just wouldn't stop moving!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Grass Fly
item.description:
Grass Fly (Chloropidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

About 3 mm. Light was fading quite fast, I couldn't get better pics.

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Hoverfly
item.description:
Hoverfly (Syrphidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Haha, I get it now! It can hover at a fixed point really well.

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Green Lacewing Larva
item.description:
Green Lacewing Larva (Chrysopidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

They haul quite a lot of trash, as such!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Carpenter Ant
item.description:
Carpenter Ant (Camponotus sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

I didn't get a lot of time to get a better pic. Pretty big kill!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Transverse Ladybird
item.description:
Transverse Ladybird (Coccinella transversalis)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Lady is here, people! Ain't it pretty!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Stable Fly
item.description:
Stable Fly (Stomoxys calcitrans)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Guess what, it did stay quite stable. Did not move for a long time!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Fruit Flies
item.description:
Fruit Flies (Tephritidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

It is their courting dance. They dance, do the tango then do little smooch!

Weather: 27.9°C, Partly cloudy

item.title: Sighting: Green Lynx Spider
item.description:
Green Lynx Spider (Peucetia viridans)

Category: Arachnid | Season: Winter

Very small spider with fairly large kill!

Weather: 28.0°C, Slight rain showers

item.title: Sighting: Braconid Wasp
item.description:
Braconid Wasp (Braconidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

About 3mm long, it sat still, but I couldn't get a neat picture because of my skill issues.

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Golden-backed Ant
item.description:
Golden-backed Ant (Polyrhachis sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

Such a neat ant! It has golden butt!

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Sighting: Chalcid Wasp
item.description:
Chalcid Wasp (Eurytomidae sp.)

Category: Insect | Season: Winter

It has some patterns on its back, should try to get a clear pic next time.

Weather: 28.2°C, Overcast

item.title: Week 2: Ants marching
item.description:
I have started talking to bugs.

Hello!

Did you know that ants do not trigger the touch-me-not plant’s defense mechanism? So cool!

Well, would you look at that stats page, so many numbers! I think I have documented quite a lot of “resident” bugs, and now the number of new species I encounter might start to decrease.

If you are planning to start a similar project, make sure you do not pick a plot right below a coconut tree. The plot I selected, however, is right beneath one. The tree’s branches look like they are ready to fall at any moment. So, this bug documentation project has turned into an adventure sport!

Note to self: Be graceful in your movements. Do not spook the bugs.

’Til next week!

item.title: Week 1: Not bad!
item.description:
My knees hurt.

Hello!

So, end of the week (well, just 4 days)! 20 species found, from very tiny to slightly bigger ones!

I saw 3 new hoppers that I hadn't seen before. They are tiny!

So, the morning light is not enough to get good quality photos, I have to bump up ISO, which leads to very grainy images. Looks like I will spend monies on a flash. Sigh.

My macro photography skills have rusted. I am hoping it will get better as the time goes on.

I also discoverd a very similar project done before by Chris Helzer. Read about it here. The photographs he has taken are very clean and precise! Now I have a benchmark to aim for!

One week at a time!

item.title: Day one!
item.description:
So it begins.

Hello world!

Welcome to a square meter project, here we like bugs. Find more about the project in the about section.

Today, I set up the fence posts on 4 corners of the patch, cleaned up the space a bit, placed an old wood piece in it. That is it. No more fiddling with the patch for the rest of the year.

My first immediate dilemma is this:

If I spot a bug within the square meter but it moves out of the boundary before I can get a photo, should I still take the picture and count it as a sighting, or should I let it go?
